thread.title: Photos: 63 years of the Alaskan Way Viaduct
thread.title_full: Photos: 63 years of the Alaskan Way Viaduct - seattlepi.com

author: DANIEL DEMAY, SEATTLEPI.COM STAFF
title: Photos: 63 years of the Alaskan Way Viaduct
text:
With the state's announcement that the Alaskan Way Viaduct will close for two weeks starting April 29, I started thinking about the fact that, at some future time, the tunnel might actually get finished.
And then they'll start tearing down the rest of the viaduct.
The thought made me a tad sentimental for the old gray hunk of Seattle's skyline.
The viaduct came to life as a way for drivers to skirt the clogged downtown streets of Seattle, a high-speed freeway to get through the city.
And, for so many years, carrying state Route 99 along above the waterfront, it has served its purpose pretty well.
But one good earthquake and a lot of years has made it a piece of infrastructure bound for the grave, and work hums along to build the tunnel to replace it.
Though the tunnel isn't set to open until spring 2018 (if it keeps its latest schedule, already more than 27 months behind the original plan), its completion will mark the end of the viaduct, and, soon after, the old concrete highway will come down.
It may be a bit early to get too wistful, but since we had an archive full of pictures of the viaduct, it seemed time to look back on the viaduct â€” from before its inception to the early steps of bringing it down.
